AE Summary

Source: vignettes/ae-summary.Rmd
ae-summary.Rmd

Overview

The AE summary analysis provides tables to summarize adverse events information. The development of AE summary analysis contains exported functions:

  • prepare_ae_summary: prepare analysis raw datasets
  • format_ae_summary: prepare analysis (mock) outdata with proper format
  • tlf_ae_summary: transfer (mock) output dataset to RTF table

We also prepare (optional) additional function to extend the analysis.

  • TODO extend_ae_specific_inference: add risk difference inference results based on M&N method.

Analysis preparation

The prepare_ae_summary function is design to be used for multiple purposes. The input of the function is a meta objects created from metalite package.

meta <- meta_ae_dummy()

The output of the function is an outdata object that contain a list of analysis raw datasets. The parameter is a group of key words available in the names(meta$parameter) and seperated by ;.

outdata <- prepare_ae_summary(meta,
  population = "apat",
  observation = "wk12",
  parameter = "any;rel;ser"
)
#> [1] "any"
#> [1] "rel"
#> [1] "ser"
outdata
#> List of 12
#>  $ meta           :List of 7
#>  $ population     : chr "apat"
#>  $ observation    : chr "wk12"
#>  $ parameter      : chr "any;rel;ser"
#>  $ n              :'data.frame': 5 obs. of  4 variables:
#>  $ order          : num [1:5] 1 100 200 300 400
#>  $ group          : chr [1:4] "Placebo" "Low Dose" "High Dose" "Total"
#>  $ reference_group: num 1
#>  $ prop           :'data.frame': 5 obs. of  4 variables:
#>  $ diff           :'data.frame': 5 obs. of  2 variables:
#>  $ n_pop          :'data.frame': 1 obs. of  4 variables:
#>  $ name           : chr [1:5] "Participants in population" "with one or more adverse events" "with no adverse events" "with drug-related{^a} adverse events" ...

The output dataset contains commonly used statistics. The variable is indexed by the order of outdata$group.

outdata$group
#> [1] "Placebo"   "Low Dose"  "High Dose" "Total"

The row is indexed by the order of outdata$name.

head(data.frame(outdata$order, outdata$name))
#>   outdata.order                         outdata.name
#> 1             1           Participants in population
#> 2           100      with one or more adverse events
#> 3           200               with no adverse events
#> 4           300 with drug-related{^a} adverse events
#> 5           400          with serious adverse events
  • n_pop: participants in population
outdata$n_pop
#>   n_1 n_2 n_3 n_4
#> 1  86  84  84 254
  • n: number of subjects with AE
head(outdata$n)
#>    n_1 n_2 n_3 n_4
#> 1   86  84  84 254
#> 2   69  77  79 225
#> 3   17   7   5  29
#> 21  44  73  70 187
#> 22   0   1   2   3
  • prop: proportion of subjects with AE
head(outdata$prop)
#>      prop_1    prop_2    prop_3    prop_4
#> 1        NA        NA        NA        NA
#> 2  80.23256 91.666667 94.047619 88.582677
#> 3  19.76744  8.333333  5.952381 11.417323
#> 21 51.16279 86.904762 83.333333 73.622047
#> 22  0.00000  1.190476  2.380952  1.181102
  • diff: risk difference compared with the reference_group.
head(outdata$diff)
#>        diff_2     diff_3
#> 1          NA         NA
#> 2   11.434109  13.815061
#> 21  35.741971  32.170543
#> 22   1.190476   2.380952
#> 3  -11.434109 -13.815061

Format output

After we have the raw analysis results, we can use format_ae_summary to prepare the outdata to create RTF tables.

tbl <- outdata |>
  format_ae_summary()
head(tbl$tbl)
#>                                    name n_1 prop_1 n_2 prop_2 n_3 prop_3 n_4
#> 1            Participants in population  86   <NA>  84   <NA>  84   <NA> 254
#> 2       with one or more adverse events  69 (80.2)  77 (91.7)  79 (94.0) 225
#> 3                with no adverse events  17 (19.8)   7  (8.3)   5  (6.0)  29
#> 21 with drug-related{^a} adverse events  44 (51.2)  73 (86.9)  70 (83.3) 187
#> 22          with serious adverse events   0  (0.0)   1  (1.2)   2  (2.4)   3
#>    prop_4
#> 1    <NA>
#> 2  (88.6)
#> 3  (11.4)
#> 21 (73.6)
#> 22  (1.2)

We can choose which measurement to display

tbl <- outdata |>
  format_ae_specific(display = c("n", "prop"))
head(tbl$tbl)
#>                                    name n_1 prop_1 n_2 prop_2 n_3 prop_3
#> 1            Participants in population  86   <NA>  84   <NA>  84   <NA>
#> 2       with one or more adverse events  69 (80.2)  77 (91.7)  79 (94.0)
#> 3                with no adverse events  17 (19.8)   7  (8.3)   5  (6.0)
#> 21 with drug-related{^a} adverse events  44 (51.2)  73 (86.9)  70 (83.3)
#> 22          with serious adverse events   0  (0.0)   1  (1.2)   2  (2.4)

We can add risk difference

tbl <- outdata |>
  format_ae_specific(display = c("n", "prop", "diff"))
head(tbl$tbl)
#>                                    name n_1 prop_1 n_2 prop_2 n_3 prop_3 diff_2
#> 1            Participants in population  86   <NA>  84   <NA>  84   <NA>     NA
#> 2       with one or more adverse events  69 (80.2)  77 (91.7)  79 (94.0)   11.4
#> 3                with no adverse events  17 (19.8)   7  (8.3)   5  (6.0)   35.7
#> 21 with drug-related{^a} adverse events  44 (51.2)  73 (86.9)  70 (83.3)    1.2
#> 22          with serious adverse events   0  (0.0)   1  (1.2)   2  (2.4)  -11.4
#>    diff_3
#> 1      NA
#> 2    13.8
#> 3    32.2
#> 21    2.4
#> 22  -13.8

We can add 95% confidence interval of M&N method. It requires extend_ae_specific_inference to perform additional calculation.

tbl <- outdata |>
  extend_ae_specific_inference() |>
  format_ae_specific(display = c("n", "prop", "diff", "diff_ci"))
head(tbl$tbl)

Mock data preparation

We can also use format_ae_summary to create mock output data.

The purpose of the mock argument is not to create a comprehensive mock table template, but a handy way to help user create a mock table that mimics the exact output layout.

Additional work is required to develop a flexible mock table generation tool (e.g.Â a dedicated mock table generation package)

tbl <- outdata |>
  format_ae_summary(mock = TRUE)
head(tbl$tbl)
#>                                   name n_1 prop_1 n_2 prop_2 n_3 prop_3 n_4
#> 1           Participants in population  xx   <NA>  xx   <NA>  xx   <NA> xxx
#> 2      with one or more adverse events  xx (xx.x)  xx (xx.x)  xx (xx.x) xxx
#> 3               with no adverse events  xx (xx.x)   x  (x.x)   x  (x.x)  xx
#> 4 with drug-related{^a} adverse events  xx (xx.x)  xx (xx.x)  xx (xx.x) xxx
#> 5          with serious adverse events   x  (x.x)   x  (x.x)   x  (x.x)   x
#>   prop_4
#> 1   <NA>
#> 2 (xx.x)
#> 3 (xx.x)
#> 4 (xx.x)
#> 5  (x.x)

RTF tables

By using tlf_ae_summary, we can transfer the output from prepare_ae_summary to an RTF table.

outdata |>
  format_ae_summary() |>
  tlf_ae_summary(
    source = "Source:  [CDISCpilot: adam-adsl; adae]",
    path_outtable = "./outtable/ae0summary1.rtf"
  )
#> The output is saved in/home/runner/work/metalite.ae/metalite.ae/vignettes/outtable/ae0summary1.rtf

The tlf_ae_summary function also provide some commonly used argument to customize the table.

outdata |>
  format_ae_summary() |>
  tlf_ae_summary(
    source = "Source:  [CDISCpilot: adam-adsl; adae]",
    col_rel_width = c(6, rep(1, 8)),
    text_font_size = 8,
    orientation = "landscape",
    path_outtable = "./outtable/ae0summary2.rtf"
  )
#> The output is saved in/home/runner/work/metalite.ae/metalite.ae/vignettes/outtable/ae0summary2.rtf

We can also generate the mock table

outdata |>
  format_ae_summary(mock = TRUE) |>
  tlf_ae_summary(
    source = "Source:  [CDISCpilot: adam-adsl; adae]",
    path_outtable = "./outtable/mock_ae0summary1.rtf"
  )
#> The output is saved in/home/runner/work/metalite.ae/metalite.ae/vignettes/outtable/mock_ae0summary1.rtf

Future developement

Features

  • Enable CI and p-value calculation using M&N method.
  • Cross check the capability in SAS standard macro to identify required features.
    • usermanuals/asr0ae0summary/asr0ae0summary-spec.docx
    • usermanuals/asr0ae0summary0analysis/asr0ae0summary0analysis-spec.docx

Technical requirements (For future development)

  • Avoiding |>, using |> to reduce dependency of magrittr.
  • The functions in the R/ folder should not depend on dplyr, tidyr etc.
